item.title: Took $82K HELOC for Kitchen Renovation—Ended Up Using Only $64K and Here's Why That Matters
item.description:
I got approved for an $82,000 HELOC to fund our kitchen renovation. The contractor quoted $75,000 for the full project, and I wanted a buffer for unexpected costs that always seem to appear.

Six months into the renovation, I’d only drawn $64,000 from the credit line. The project cost less than quoted, I found cheaper material alternatives, and I postponed some non-essential upgrades.

That $18,000 difference between approved credit line and actual usage saved me $3,240 in interest in the first year alone—and it’s the perfect example of why HELOC flexibility matters more than just rate comparisons.

item.title: FHA 203(k) Refinance: I Renovated My Home Without Selling—Here's How It Worked
item.description:
I bought my home in 2021 for $245,000 with a conventional loan at 7.2% interest.

By 2024:

  • My home was worth approximately $285,000 (modest appreciation)
  • My kitchen and bathrooms were still original 1980s condition (outdated)
  • I wanted to renovate but had no cash savings (spent everything on the down payment in 2021)

My dilemma:

  • Option #1: Save $40,000 for renovations (would take 3-4 years)
  • Option #2: Home equity loan or HELOC (rates were 9-10%—too high)
  • Option #3: Sell, buy a renovated home (lose $18,000+ in selling costs and moving expenses)

Then my neighbor mentioned: “Have you looked into FHA 203(k) refinance? I renovated my kitchen without selling.”
